netsquid.components.qprocessor

A quantum processor adds quantum computation capabilities to a QuantumMemory.

Instructions are executed on a processor either directly or via a QuantumProgram. These instructions are matched to the PhysicalInstructions of the processor, which are assigned to specific memory positions. Such an assignment to memory positions is called a topology.

A processor can execute instructions in parallel if its PhysicalInstructions support it. It is possible to execute instructions that do not match to physical instructions if the physical parameter is set to False.

While a program is being executed the processor is busy (locked), and it is not possible to access its qubits via peek, pop, operate or measure.

Examples

Example imports:

>>> import netsquid as ns
>>> from netsquid.components.qprocessor import *
>>> from netsquid.components.instructions import *
>>> from netsquid.components.qprogram import *
>>> from netsquid.components.models.qerrormodels import *

Example of specifying two quantum programs and running them:

>>> qproc = QuantumProcessor(
...     "TestQPD", num_positions=4,
...     mem_noise_models=[DepolarNoiseModel(500)] * 4, phys_instructions=[
...         PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_INIT, duration=2.5, parallel=True),
...         PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_X, duration=1, topology=[1,2,3],
...                             quantum_noise_model=T1T2NoiseModel(T1=0.5)),
...         PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_CNOT, duration=2, topology=[(2, 1), (1, 3)]),
...         PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_MEASURE, duration=3, parallel=True)])
...
>>> # First program
>>> prog1 = QuantumProgram(num_qubits=2)
>>> q1, q2 = prog1.get_qubit_indices(2)
>>> prog1.apply(INSTR_INIT, q1)
>>> prog1.apply(INSTR_INIT, q2)
>>> prog1.apply(INSTR_X, q1)
>>> prog1.apply(INSTR_CNOT, [q1, q2])
>>> prog1.apply(INSTR_SIGNAL, physical=False)
>>> prog1.apply(INSTR_MEASURE, q1, output_key="m1")
>>> prog1.apply(INSTR_MEASURE, q2, output_key="m2")
...
>>> # Second program
>>> class CustomQProgram(QuantumProgram):
...     default_num_qubits = 2
...
...     def program(self):
...         q1, q2 = self.get_qubit_indices(2)
...         self.apply(INSTR_INIT, q1)
...         self.apply(INSTR_INIT, q2)
...         yield self.run()
...         self.apply(INSTR_X, q1)
...         self.apply(INSTR_CNOT, [q1, q2])
...         self.apply(INSTR_SIGNAL, physical=False)
...         self.apply(INSTR_MEASURE, q1, output_key="m1")
...         self.apply(INSTR_MEASURE, q2, output_key="m2")
...         yield self.run(parallel=False)
...
...
>>> prog2 = CustomQProgram()
...
>>> # Run programs
>>> qproc.execute_program(prog1, qubit_mapping=[1, 3])
>>> ns.sim_run()
>>> print(prog1.output) 
...
>>> qproc.execute_program(prog2, qubit_mapping=[2, 1])
>>> ns.sim_run()
>>> print(prog2.output)

When executing a program you can specify keyword arguments that are passed through to the program.

>>> class ParamProgram(QuantumProgram):
...
...     def program(self, a, b=1):
...         self.output["a"] = a
...         self.output["b"] = b
...         yield self.run()
...
>>> qproc = QuantumProcessor("TestQPD")
>>> prog = ParamProgram()
>>> qproc.execute_program(prog, a=4, b=2)
>>> ns.sim_run()
>>> prog.output["a"]
4
>>> prog.output["b"]
2
class netsquid.components.qprocessor.ProcessorStatus(value)

Bases: IntEnum

Status of a quantum processor.

IDLE

Quantum processor is ready to run a quantum program or instruction.

Type:

int

RUNNING

Quantum processor is busy running a quantum program or instruction. Will block requests to access memory positions or start running another program or instruction.

Type:

int

FAILED

The last program to run on the quantum processor failed. Otherwise the processor is IDLE i.e. ready to run a new program.

Type:

int

PAUSED

Quantum processor is running a quantum program or instruction, i.e. same as RUNNING, but is currently paused in its execution.

Type:

int

class netsquid.components.qprocessor.QuantumProcessor(name, num_positions=1, mem_noise_models=None, phys_instructions=None, mem_pos_types=None, fallback_to_nonphysical=False, properties=None, **kwargs)

Bases: QuantumMemory

A quantum memory that can execute quantum programs or instructions.

Instructions are executed by matching to the specified:obj:~netsquid.components.qprocessor.PhysicalInstructions.

A processor can execute instructions in parallel if its PhysicalInstructions support it. It is possible to execute instructions that do not match to physical instructions if the physical parameter is set to False.

While a program is being executed the processor is busy (locked), and it is not possible to access its qubits via peek, pop, operate or measure.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of quantum processor for identification purposes.

  • num_positions (int, optional) – Number of available memory positions.

  • mem_noise_models (QuantumErrorModel or list of QuantumErrorModel or None, optional) – Noise model(s) for the memory position(s). If a single model is specified, it is assigned to all the memory positions. Otherwise the list of models should match the number of positions. If None, no noise models are assigned.

  • phys_instructions (list of PhysicalInstruction or None, optional) – Physical instructions available on the quantum processor. Physical instructions can also be added after construction using add_instruction().

  • fallback_to_nonphysical (bool, optional) – If True, instructions that do not match to a physical instruction will be executed as non-physical instructions. Otherwise a MissingInstructionError is raised.

  • mem_pos_types (list of str or None, optional) – Types of the qubit(s) held by the memory position(s). Meta identifier. If None, all types will be None. Otherwise length of list must match num_positions.

  • properties (dict or None, optional) – Extra properties associated with this component.

evtype_program_done

Static event type that signals a program has succesfully finished execution.

Type:

EventType

evtype_program_fail

Static event type that signals a program has failed during execution.

Type:

EventType

Properties:

num_positions (int, immutable) – Number of memory positions.

Ports:

  • qout – Port used to output (emit) qubits from the quantum memory. The items of the emitted Message are of type Qubit.

  • qout{0..(N-1)} – Ports used to output (emit) qubits from the quantum memory. Each port is directly linked to the memory position, such that position x will output on port qoutx. Instead of emitting all qubits on one port and combining them in a Message, each output port will have a separate message containing only the Qubit.

  • qin – Port used to input (absorb) qubits to the quantum memory. The items of an input Message are expected to be of type Qubit. The qubits in this list will be put on the memory positions in the same order by default e.g. a list with one qubit will override position 0. The meta of the input Message can contain the meta fields qm_positions, qm_replace, qm_ready_evtype, and qm_check_positions. These correspond to the optional input parameters of the put() method.

  • qin{0..(N-1)} – Ports used to input (absorb) a qubit to a specific memory position in the quantum memory. Similar to the qin port except that the meta fields qm_positions and qm_check_positions are ignored.

Models:

  • qin_noise_model (QuantumErrorModel) – Apply absorption noise to incoming qubits.

  • qout_noise_model (QuantumErrorModel) – Apply emission noise to outgoing qubits.

Subcomponents:

mem_position{0…(N-1)} – Memory positions held by this quantum memory.

Notes

A quantum processor must first have physical instructions in order to physically execute programs.

A topology is defined as the set of memory position tuples a physical instruction acts on. For example, a single qubit gate may have the topology [(0,), (2,), (4,)], and a two qubit gate [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, 2)]. A topology of None means the instruction can act on any permutation of memory positions matching the number of qubits it targets.

Examples

Create a quantum processor, adding its physical instructions in different ways:

>>> from netsquid.components import instructions as ins
...
>>> qproc = QuantumProcessor("TestQPD", num_positions=4, phys_instructions=[
...     PhysicalInstruction(ins.INSTR_X, duration=1, parallel=True, topology=[1, 3]),
...     PhysicalInstruction(ins.INSTR_CNOT, duration=2, topology=[(0, 1), (2, 3)]),
...     PhysicalInstruction(ins.INSTR_MEASURE, duration=3, parallel=True),
...     PhysicalInstruction(ins.INSTR_MEASURE_X, duration=2)],
... )
...
>>> # Add another physical instruction
>>> qproc.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_H, duration=1.5, topology=[2, 3]))
...
>>> # Create and add a new physical instruction
>>> qproc.add_instruction(INSTR_H, duration=4, topology=[0],
...                       q_noise_model=T1T2NoiseModel(T1=0.5))

Using composite instructions you can build up a new instruction based on existing instructions. A quantum processor that can physically do X and Z gates on position 0 but not Y gates can define an Y instruction as:

>>> qproc = QuantumProcessor("test_processor1", num_positions=3)
>>> qproc.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(ins.INSTR_X, duration=2,
...                                                    topology=[0]))
>>> qproc.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(ins.INSTR_Z, duration=4,
...                                                    topology=[0]))
>>> qproc.add_composite_instruction(ins.INSTR_Y, [(ins.INSTR_X, 0), (ins.INSTR_Z, 0)],
...                                 topology=[0])

See add_composite_instruction() for an extended example. Also see the example in PhysicalIndex on how to define composite instructions that require more qubits than the original instruction.

active_instructions(self)

Return the instructions currently executed.

The list is sorted, first on start time, then on end time.

Returns:

The list containing the start time, end time, the physical instruction and the positions.

Return type:

list

add_composite_instruction(self, instruction, composition, topology=None)

Add a compiled/composite instruction to this quantum processor.

Compiled instructions are instructions that are composed of multiple lower level physical instructions. The instructions that this instruction composes of are applied recursively when applying this instruction.

This makes it possible for example to define INSTR_Z as applying INSTR_S twice if a PhysicalInstruction was given for INSTR_S.

Parameters:

  • instruction (Instruction) – Instruction to be carried out.

  • composition (list of tuples) – The instructions that compile into this instruction. Each entry is a tuple of the form (Instruction, indices). Where indices is an int or PhysicalIndex, or a tuple thereof. These indices are positions relative to the topology of the composite instruction; unless explicitly wrapped with a PhysicalIndex.

  • topology (list of tuple of int or None, optional) – Memory position(s) to enable instruction for. If instruction applies to multiple qubits, a tuple should be specified for each applicable combination e.g. [(0,1), (1,0)] for a controlled gate that can act in both directions. None acts as a wildcard: the instruction is assigned to all possible position permutations. An instruction that acts on no qubits has topology [()] i.e. an empty tuple. Default None.

Examples

A quantum processor that can physically do X and Z gates on position 0 but not Y gates can define an Y instruction as:

>>> from netsquid.components.qprocessor import (QuantumProcessor,
...                                             PhysicalInstruction)
>>> from netsquid.components.instructions import (INSTR_X, INSTR_Y,
...                                               INSTR_Z, INSTR_CNOT,
...                                               INSTR_CZ, INSTR_H)
...
>>> qproc = QuantumProcessor("test_processor1", num_positions=3)
>>> qproc.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_X, duration=2,
...                                                    topology=[0]))
>>> qproc.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_Z, duration=4,
...                                                    topology=[0]))
>>> qproc.add_composite_instruction(INSTR_Y, [(INSTR_X, 0), (INSTR_Z, 0)],
...                                topology=[0])

A CNOT gate might be defined as follows if only CZ and H are available.

>>> qproc.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_H, duration=3))
>>> qproc.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_CZ, duration=8))
>>> qproc.add_composite_instruction(INSTR_CNOT, [(INSTR_H, 1),
...                                             (INSTR_CZ, (0, 1)),
...                                             (INSTR_H, 1)])

Instructions can be defined recursively. In this example when applying the I gate, the T gate will be applied 8 times.

>>> qproc2 = QuantumProcessor("test_processor2", num_positions=2)
>>> qproc2.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_T, duration=1))
>>> qproc2.add_composite_instruction(INSTR_S, [(INSTR_T, 0), (INSTR_T, 0)])
>>> qproc2.add_composite_instruction(INSTR_Z, [(INSTR_S, 0), (INSTR_S, 0)])
>>> qproc2.add_composite_instruction(INSTR_I, [(INSTR_Z, 0), (INSTR_Z, 0)])

Also see the example in PhysicalIndex on how to define composite instructions that require more qubits than the original instruction.

add_instruction(self, instruction, duration, topology=None, q_noise_model=None, c_noise_model=None)

Add a program instruction to the processor’s memory position(s).

Creates a corresponding PhysicalInstruction for the specified positions.

Parameters:

  • instruction (Instruction) – Instruction to be added to quantum processor.

  • duration (float) – Physical duration of the instruction [ns].

  • topology (list of tuple of int or None, optional) – Memory position(s) to enable instruction for. If instruction applies to multiple qubits, a tuple should be specified for each applicable combination e.g. [(0,1), (1,0)] for a controlled gate that can act in both directions. If None, instruction is assigned to all possible position permutations.

  • q_noise_model (QuantumErrorModel or None, optional) – Quantum noise model to apply before executing instruction.

  • c_noise_model (ClassicalErrorModel or None, optional) – Classical noise model to apply out output of instruction.

add_physical_instruction(self, phys_instr)

Add a physical instruction to the processor’s memory positions(s).

Physical instructions are indexed by their instruction name per topology. If a physical instruction with the same name already exists for a topology, including the case of no topology, it is overridden.

Parameters:

phys_instr (PhysicalInstruction) – Physical instruction to be added to quantum processor.

Notes

Internally the physical instructions are stored by their topology in a dict. If no specific topology is given, they are stored with a wildcard key.

add_ports(self, names)

Add ports to this component.

Added ports are accessible via ports.

Parameters:

names (list of str) – Names of ports.

Returns:

List of the ports with the given names.

Return type:

list of Port

Notes

If a port with this name already exists it is also returned in the list, but not overwritten.

add_property(self, name, value=None, mutable=True, value_type=None, value_constraints=None)

Add a property to this component.

Properties can be accessed and modified via the properties attribute.

If a property with this name already exists, an attempt will be made to set the new value.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the property.

  • value (Any) – Value of the property.

  • mutable (bool, optional) – Whether the property is mutable.

  • value_type (type, optional) – Type of this property

  • value_constraints (~netsquid.util.constrainedmap.ValueConstraint or list of ~netsquid.util.constrainedmap.ValueConstraint , optional) – constraint checks to verify if value is a valid value

add_subcomponent(self, component, name=None, forward_input=None, forward_output=None, add_ports=False)

Add a subcomponent to this component.

Subcomponents can be accessed using the subcomponents property.

If a component already exists with this name identifier it will be replaced.

Parameters:

  • component (Component) – Component to add.

  • name (str or None, optional) – Custom name identifier for component. If None (default), the name of the component being added is used. If a component using the same name already exists it is overridden.

  • forward_input (list of tuple of str or None, optional) – Names of ports to forward input from parent component to subcomponent. Each tuple in this list consist of two port names: The first port name is the port of the parentcomponent. The second port name is the port of the subcomponent.

  • forward_output (list of tuple of str or None, optional) – Names of ports to forward output from subcomponent to parent component. Each tuple in this list consist of two port names: The first port name is the port of the parentcomponent. The second port name is the port of the subcomponent.

  • add_ports (bool, optional) – If ports should be created if they do not yet exist. Default False

Raises:

ComponentHierarchyError – If the component to be added is already related to this component as a sub or super component at any depth. Or if the component is already a subcomponent of an other component.

Example

Instead of

>>> from netsquid.components import Component
...
>>> parent = Component("parent", port_names=["in_p", "out_p"])
>>> child = Component("child", port_names=["in_c", "out_c"])
>>> parent.add_subcomponent(child)
>>> parent.ports["in_p"].forward_input(child.ports["in_c"])
>>> child.ports["out_c"].forward_output(parent.ports["out_p"])

One can do

>>> parent = Component("parent", port_names=["in_p", "out_p"])
>>> child = Component("child", port_names=["in_c", "out_c"])
>>> parent.add_subcomponent(child,
...     forward_input=[("in_p", "in_c")],
...     forward_output=[("out_p", "out_c")])
busy

Whether the quantum processor is executing a program i.e. its status is running or paused.

Type:

bool

delta_time(self, positions, bool check_positions=True)

Return time(s) since qubit(s) on memory positions were last accessed.

Interacting with qubits, e.g. via peek() or operate(), updates the last access time.

Parameters:

  • positions (int or list of int) – Memory position(s) to return delta times for.

  • check_positions (bool, optional) – Whether to check validity of specified positions. If true, will raise an exception if positions are invalid.

Returns:

The times each qubit has spent on its memory position since its last access. If a memory position is empty the list entry is 0 [ns].

Return type:

list of float

discard(self, positions, check_positions=True)

Discard qubit(s) from the quantum memory.

The qubits are removed from their memory positions.

Parameters:

  • positions (int or list of int) – Position(s) of the qubit(s) to discard.

  • check_positions (bool, optional) – Whether to check validity of specified positions. If true, will raise an exception if positions are invalid. Default is True.

execute_instruction(self, instruction, qubit_mapping=None, str output_key='instr', bool physical=True, bool check_qubit_mapping=True, **parameters)

Run a single instruction on the quantum processor.

If physical is True, the instruction is matched to a physical instruction on the processor, and a quantum program containing this single instruction is created and run. If the instruction is non-physical, it is executed instantly and without noise.

A failing instruction will raise the exception that caused it to fail. Only in the case of a non-physical instruction can this exception be caught immediately.

Parameters:

  • instruction (Instruction) – Instruction to run.

  • qubit_mapping (list of int or None, optional) – Mapping of program qubit indices to memory positions. List can be empty. If None, program indices are mapped directly to memory indices.

  • output_key (str, optional) – Dictionary key to store instruction output with. Default is to store instruction output to instr.

  • physical (bool, optional) – Whether to interpret this instruction as being physical. If non-physical it will execute instantly and without noise.

  • check_qubit_mapping (bool, optional) – Whether to check validity of the specified qubit mapping. If true, will raise an exception if mapping is invalid.

  • **parameters – Additional keyword arguments to pass to the instruction.

Returns:

  • dict – Output dictionary for the executed instruction in which output will be stored as output_key.

  • float – Expected run time of instruction.

  • EventExpression – The EventExpression that will trigger when the instruction finishes.

execute_program(self, program, qubit_mapping=None, bool error_on_fail=False, bool check_qubit_mapping=True, **parameters)

Run a quantum program.

Matches the program instructions to the physical instructions on the processor. Will execute the instructions of the program in parallel if specified and physically possible.

An event of type evtype_program_done will be scheduled when the program finishes successfully, otherwise an event of type evtype_program_fail is scheduled upon failure.

Parameters:

  • program (QuantumProgram) – Quantum program to run.

  • qubit_mapping (list of int or None, optional) – Mapping of program qubit indices to memory positions. List can be empty. If None, program indices are mapped directly to memory indices.

  • error_on_fail (bool, optional) – Whether to raise the exception that is caught if this program fails. The default is to store the exception (see fail_exception()) and not to raise it.

  • check_qubit_mapping (bool, optional) – Whether to check validity of the specified qubit mapping. If true, will raise an exception if mapping is invalid.

  • **parameters (keyword arguments) – Keyword arguments that will passed into the QuantumProgram.program() call.

Returns:

The EventExpression that will trigger when the program finishes.

Return type:

EventExpression

Notes

The program output is retrievable as the output attribute of the specified program.

fail_exception

The exception that caused the last quantum program to fail, if any.

Type:

Exception or None

fallback_to_nonphysical

If True, instructions that do not match to a physical instruction will be executed as non-physical instructions. Otherwise a MissingInstructionError is raised.

Type:

bool

get_composite_instruction_decomposition(self, instruction, positions=None)

Get the decomposition of an instruction at a given position

Parameters:

  • instruction (Instruction) – The instruction to get the decomposition of.

  • positions (tuple of int or None, optional) – Memory position(s) to get the decomposition of the instructions for. Tuple can be empty. If None or -1, returns decomposition for the wildcard. Default None

Returns:

The tuples are the form (Instruction, indices). Where indices is an int or PhysicalIndex, or a tuple thereof.

Will return None if no such decomposition exists.

Return type:

None or list of tuples

get_composite_instructions(self, positions=None)

Get a set of composite instructions at the given positions.

Parameters:

positions (tuple of int or None, optional) – Memory position(s) to return composite instructions for. Tuple can be empty. If None, returns result for all topologies.

Returns:

Instructions that are available as composite instruction at the give position.

Return type:

set of Instruction

get_finished_instrs(self)

Get all finished instructions in reversed order.

When a job is finished the instruction and end time are added to this list.

Returns:

Reversed ordered list of finished instructions and their end time.

Return type:

list of tuple(Instruction, float)

Parameters:

  • positions (int or tuple of int) – Memory position(s) of physical instruction.

Returns:

Duration of a the matching physical instruction.

Return type:

float

get_matching_positions(self, name, value=None)

Get index of memory positions that match a property name and/or value.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of property.

  • value (Any or None, optional) – Value of property. If None, all positions with this property name are returned.

Returns:

List of memory positions indices matching the property.

Return type:

list of int

get_matching_qubits(self, metafield, value=None)

Get index of qubits on memory positions that match a meta data field and/or value.

Parameters:

  • metafield (str) – Meta field key.

  • value (Any or None, optional) – Meta field value. If None all positions with a qubit matching the metafield are returned.

Returns:

List of memory positions indices matching the qubit meta field.

Return type:

list of int

get_physical_instructions(self, positions=None, instruction=None)

Get a set of physical instructions.

Parameters:

  • positions (tuple of int or None, optional) – Memory position(s) to return physical instructions for. Tuple can be empty. If None, returns result for all topologies.

  • instruction (Instruction or None, optional) – The instruction to match a physical instruction for. If None, returns result for all instructions.

Returns:

Physical instructions.

Return type:

set of PhysicalInstruction

get_position_empty(self, position=0)

DEPRECATED.

get_position_used(self, position=0)

DEPRECATED.

get_program_duration(self, program, qubit_mapping=None, bool check_qubit_mapping=True)

Calculate duration of a quantum program on this processor.

Will only return the duration of the first instruction sequence i.e. up to first yield statement. Result will be unreliable if the program contains random classical control logic.

Parameters:

  • program (QuantumProgram) – Quantum program to calculate duration for.

  • qubit_mapping (list of int or None, optional) – Mapping of program qubit indices to memory positions. List can be empty. If None, program indices are mapped directly to memory indices.

  • check_qubit_mapping (bool, optional) – Whether to check validity of the specified qubit mapping. If true, will raise an exception if mapping is invalid.

Returns:

Expected run time of first instruction sequence i.e. up to first yield statement.

Return type:

float

has_subcomponent(self, component)

Whether argument is a subcomponent of this component at any level.

Returns:

True if component contained as a subcomponent at any level, otherwise False.

Return type:

bool

has_supercomponent(self, component)

Whether argument is a supercomponent of this component at any level.

measure(self, positions=None, observable=Z, meas_operators=None, bool discard=False, bool skip_noise=False, bool check_positions=True)

Measure the qubit(s) at the given position(s).

By default will apply quantum noise before measurement. The qubits will remain on the memory unless discard is True. Remaining qubits will have their access times updated. Measurement operators should be single- or n-qubit operators. n should match the number of position given.

See measure().

Parameters:

  • positions (int or list of int or None, optional) – Position(s) of which the Qubit(s) should be measured. If None, all memory positions are measured

  • observable (Operator, optional) – Hermitian operator to measure qubit with. Default is the Z observable.

  • meas_operators (list or tuple of Operator or None, optional) – A list of operators M_i that should satisfy the completeness relation \(\sum_i^N M_i^{\dagger} M_i = I`\). If not None, will override the observable parameter.

  • discard (bool, optional) – Whether to discard the qubit(s) after measurement. If True the qubits will also be removed from the quantum memory.

  • skip_noise (bool, optional) – Whether to apply quantum noise to the qubit(s) before measurement.

  • check_positions (bool, optional) – Whether to check validity of specified positions. If true, will raise an exception if positions are invalid.

Returns:

  • list of int – List of measurement results. For an observable, 0 if positive eigenstate measured, otherwise 1. For measurement operators, the index of the operator measured.

  • list of float – List of probabilities with which results occurred.

Raises:

  • MemPositionEmptyError – If a memory position to be operated on is empty.

  • TypeError – If the measurement operators aren’t a list or tuple.

measure_faulty(self, positions=None, observable=Z, double p0=0, double p1=0, bool discard=False, bool skip_noise=False, bool check_positions=True)

Measure the qubit(s) at the given position(s) with a specified probability for error.

This is implemented as a perfect measurement with the error applied classically to the reported outcome. That is, with some probability, the reported outcome does not correspond to the state to which the qubit has collapsed. If the qubits are kept after measurement, the post-measurement state is updated as usual.

For the DM formalism the post measurement state will take the error probabilities into account as follows:

\[\rho(m) = \sum_i \frac{p(m|i)p(i) }{\sum_j p(m|j)p(j)}\vert \psi_i \rangle\langle \psi_i \vert\]

where \(m\) is the measurement outcome, \(p(m|i)\) is the probability we get outcome \(m\) had we gotten outcome \(i\) from the perfect measurement, and \(p(i)\) is the probability we get outcome \(i\) from this perfect measurement. \(\vert\psi_i\rangle\) is the eigenstate associated with outcome \(i\).

Parameters:

  • positions (int or list of int or None, optional) – Position(s) of which the Qubit(s) should be measured. If None, all memory positions are measured

  • observable (Operator, optional) – Hermitian operator to measure qubit with. Default is the Z observable.

  • p0 (float, optional) – The probability of measuring outcome 0 incorrectly. Default is 0.

  • p1 (float, optional) – The probability of measuring outcome 1 incorrectly. Default is 0.

  • discard (bool, optional) – Whether to discard the qubit(s) after measurement. If True the qubits will also be removed from the quantum memory.

  • skip_noise (bool, optional) – Whether to apply quantum noise to the qubit(s) before measurement.

  • check_positions (bool, optional) – Whether to check validity of specified positions. If true, will raise an exception if positions are invalid.

Returns:

  • list of int – List of measurement results. For an observable, 0 if positive eigenstate measured, otherwise 1.

  • list of float – List of probabilities with which results occurred.

Raises:

MemPositionEmptyError – If a memory position to be operated on is empty.

mem_positions

memory positions of this quantum memory.

Type:

list of MemoryPosition

models

the models associated with this component.

Models that a component can hold are strictly define at construction. To change the model use: models[name_model] = model().

Type:

Type:

Type:

operate(self, operator, positions, bool skip_noise=False, bool check_positions=True)

Operate on the qubit(s) at the given position(s).

By default will apply quantum noise to the qubits before the quantum operation. The qubits will remain on the memory, and their access time are updated.

See operate().

Parameters:

  • operator (Operator) – Operator acting on qubits

  • positions (int, list of int) – Position(s) of the Qubit(s) to operate on.

  • skip_noise (bool, optional) – Whether to apply quantum noise to the qubit(s) before the operation.

  • check_positions (bool, optional) – Whether to check validity of specified positions. If true, will raise an exception if positions are invalid.

Raises:

MemPositionEmptyError – If a memory position to be operated on is empty.

peek(self, positions, skip_noise=False, check_positions=True)

Peek at qubit(s) from the quantum memory.

By default quantum noise will be applied to qubit(s), which can be a function of the time since the qubit was last accessed.

Peeking at qubits updates their last accessed time.

Parameters:

  • positions (int or list of int) – Position(s) of the qubit(s) to pop.

  • skip_noise (bool, optional) – Whether to apply quantum noise to the peeked qubit(s).

  • check_positions (bool, optional) – Whether to check validity of specified positions. If true, will raise an exception if positions are invalid.

Returns:

Qubit(s) at the given position of the memory. If the memory position is empty the list entry is None.

Return type:

list of Qubit

pop(self, positions, noise_positions=None, skip_noise=False, check_positions=True, meta_data=None, positional_qout=False)

Emit qubit(s) from the quantum memory.

The qubits are output as a message via the qout port. Popped qubits are removed from their memory positions. If the memory position(s) are empty the item entry in the message is None.

By default quantum memory noise will be applied to qubit(s), which can be a function of the time since the qubit was last accessed. The popped qubits are also subject to a possible emission noise model.

Parameters:

  • positions (int or list of int) – Position(s) of the qubit(s) to pop.

  • noise_positions (list of int) – Additional qubit(s) to include in emission noise. These are added after the popped qubits list when passed to the model.

  • skip_noise (bool, optional) – Whether to apply quantum memory noise to the popped qubit(s).

  • check_positions (bool, optional) – Whether to check validity of specified positions. If true, will raise an exception if positions are invalid.

  • meta_data (dict or None, optional) – Additional meta data to add to the emitted message. Will override any existing meta data.

  • positional_qout (bool, optional) – Use the qout{0..(N-1)} ports instead of the general qout port. Default False. Each qubit will have a separate message and metadata.

Returns:

For convenience, the qubit(s) emitted as a message via the output port are also returned for immediate inspection.

Return type:

list of Qubit

Notes

Meta data of memory positions is added to message in order of positions i.e. later qubits will override meta data of previous qubits in list.

ports

ports belonging to this component.

Type:

ConstrainedMap

put(self, qubits, positions=None, ready_evtype=None, replace=True, check_positions=True)

Put one or more qubits into the memory at the given position(s).

Has the same affect as inputting qubits onto the “qin” port via a message.

Parameters:

  • qubits (Qubit or list of Qubit) – Qubit(s) to store.

  • positions (int, list of int or None, optional) – Position(s) where the Qubit(s) should be put. If no value is given, the n qubit(s) will be put on the positions 0:n.

  • ready_evtype (EventType or None, optional) – Type of event to schedule when the qubit is put onto its memory position. If None, the default event type of the memory position is scheduled.

  • replace (bool, optional) – Whether to replace existing qubits. If False, an exception is raised. Default is True.

  • check_positions (bool, optional) – Whether to check validity of specified positions. If true, will raise an exception if positions are invalid.

Raises:

MemPositionInUseError – Raised if a memory positions is in use and replace is set to False.

Notes

When a qubit is put on a position that is already contains a qubit, the previous qubit is replaced (but not discarded).

rem_subcomponent(self, name)

Remove a subcomponent from this component.

Outgoing port connections are disconnected to keep the hierarchy consistent; That means that any port connections to the parent or siblings are disconnected. Input ports to subcomponents remain.

Parameters:

name (str) – Name identifier for component.

reset(self)

Clear all memory positions and stop any running program.

After a reset the quantum memory has all its positions available for putting new qubits.

Notes

Will dismiss any user specified callback event handlers. Does not dismiss internal event handlers.

class netsquid.components.qprocessor.PhysicalIndex(position)

Bases: object

Helper class for composite instructions to indicate instruction acts on a physical (hardcoded) index outside the scope of instruction.

Parameters:

position (int) – physical index of the quantum memory the instruction acts on

Examples

Consider the following scenario: You have two processors at which you want to do an X gate on the qubit on position 1, using the same program. However one of the processors can only do the X gate on position 0, but is able to swap the qubits on position 0 and 1. In that case that processor is able to perform the X gate on qubit 1, but it requires an additional qubit position to execute.

To do an X gate on the qubit in position 1 or 2 you would need to SWAP the qubit with position 0, perform X on qubit 0, and swap back. INSTR_X is an instruction that only acts on one qubit, yet now we require extra qubits to perform the one qubit gate. The positions of those extra qubits can be defined using this PhysicalIndex class.

>>> from netsquid.components.qprocessor import QuantumProcessor, PhysicalInstruction
>>> from netsquid.components.instructions import INSTR_X, INSTR_SWAP, INSTR_INIT
...
>>> ns.sim_reset()
>>> qproc1 = QuantumProcessor("qproc1", num_positions=3)
>>> qproc1.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_INIT, duration=1))
>>> qproc1.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_X, duration=1,
...                                                     topology=[0]))
>>> qproc1.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_SWAP, duration=2))

>>> qproc1.add_composite_instruction(INSTR_X, [(INSTR_SWAP, (PhysicalIndex(0), 0)),
...                                           (INSTR_X, PhysicalIndex(0)),
...                                           (INSTR_SWAP, (PhysicalIndex(0), 0))],
...                                 topology=[1, 2])

We have another processor that can do an X gate directly on qubit 1.

>>> qproc2 = QuantumProcessor("qproc2", num_positions=2)
>>> qproc2.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_INIT, duration=1))
>>> qproc2.add_physical_instruction(PhysicalInstruction(INSTR_X, duration=1))

We want a program that performs an X gate on qubit 1 to be able to run on both quantum processors

>>> from netsquid.components.qprogram import QuantumProgram
>>> program = QuantumProgram()
>>> program.apply(INSTR_INIT, 1)
>>> program.apply(INSTR_X, 1)
>>> qproc1.execute_program(program, error_on_fail=True)
>>> qproc2.execute_program(program, error_on_fail=True)

qproc2 finishes at \(t = 2\) and qproc1 finishes at \(t = 1 + 2 + 1 + 2 = 6\) (INIT + SWAP + X + SWAP). They run in parallel, so the final time is 6. The qubits at position 1 are in the \(\vert1\rangle\) state

>>> ns.sim_run()
>>> ns.sim_time()
6.0
>>> ns.qubits.reduced_dm(qproc1.peek(1)[0])
array([[0.+0.j, 0.+0.j],
       [0.+0.j, 1.+0.j]])
>>> ns.qubits.reduced_dm(qproc2.peek(1)[0])
array([[0.+0.j, 0.+0.j],
       [0.+0.j, 1.+0.j]])
>>> ns.sim_reset()
class netsquid.components.qprocessor.PhysicalInstruction(instruction, double duration, topology=None, quantum_noise_model=None, classical_noise_model=None, bool parallel=False, apply_q_noise_after=True, **parameters)

Bases: object

Physical realisation of an instruction for a quantum processor.

Represents the duration and noise of an instruction.

Parameters:

  • instruction (Instruction) – Instruction to be carried out.

  • duration (float) – Physical duration of the instruction [ns].

  • topology (list of tuple of int or None, optional) – Memory position(s) to enable instruction for. If instruction applies to multiple qubits, a tuple should be specified for each applicable combination e.g. [(0,1), (1,0)] for a controlled gate that can act in both directions. None acts as a wildcard: instruction is assigned to all possible position permutations. An instruction that acts on no qubits has topology [()] i.e. an empty tuple.

  • quantum_noise_model (QuantumErrorModel or None, optional) – Quantum noise model to apply to qubits after executing the instruction.

  • classical_noise_model (ClassicalErrorModel or None, optional) – Classical noise model to apply to instruction output.

  • parallel (bool, optional) – Whether this instruction can be run in parallel to others.

  • apply_q_noise_after (bool, optional) – Whether to apply quantum noise after instruction instead of before.

  • **parameters – Runtime parameters to pass to the instruction as keyword arguments. These will override any matching parameters specified in the quantum program.

apply_q_noise(self, list qubits)

Helper function to apply quantum noise to qubits.

Parameters:

qubits (list of {Qubit, None})

apply_q_noise_after

Whether to apply quantum noise after instruction instead of before.

Type:

bool

classical_noise_model

ClassicalErrorModel or None: Classical noise model to apply to instruction output.

duration

Physical duration of instruction [ns].

Type:

float

instr_params

Runtime parameters to pass to the instruction as keyword arguments. These will override any matching parameters specified in the quantum program.

Type:

dict

instruction

Instruction to be carried out.

Type:

Instruction

parallel

Whether this instruction can be run in parallel to others.

Type:

bool

quantum_noise_model

QuantumErrorModel or None: Quantum noise model to apply to qubits after executing the instruction.

topology

list: List of qubits (or tuple of qubits for multi qubit instructions) that this instruction can act on None if it can act on all qubits .
